posts.name:
Jeff Roberts
Jeff Roberts
posts.content:
Where Are Digital Transformation Dollars Going?

Deloitte's latest article breaks down where organizations are focusing their digital transformation budgets, and it's eye-opening. Investments are leaning heavily into areas like data analytics, cloud infrastructure, and customer experience—technologies that don't just sound impressive but actually improve agility and business outcomes.

What stood out to me? Companies are moving beyond chasing the latest tools. They're aligning spending with clear, measurable goals. It's a shift from "let's adopt the newest tech" to "how does this directly drive long-term value?"

As budgets grow, leaders face a challenge: making sure every dollar delivers real impact.

How is your organization tackling this? Are your tech investments moving the needle in meaningful ways?

Read more on Deloitte:

comments.commentText: Hi Jeff… our digital transformation is anchored on value… in addition to financial benefits, we are focused on establishing platforms(people, process, data and technology) which are scalable, resilient and true enablers for our company’s growth strategy. We have a program which is nimble and can react to any changes in priority and more importantly, adapt to any critical unknowns when they become known.

This is a great post. Measuring the impact of a digital transformation is important as well.

Many times Digital Transformation Projects are embarked on, but many organizations cannot determine a baseline of productivity before the project and then measure the effectiveness of the new solution, post-implementation.

This is somethingcan help with. PROVE the value of the project using data from Produce8.

posts.name:
Walter Crosby
Walter Crosby
posts.content:
Think your underperformers are just hurting your bottom line? Think again.

Every day you keep a poor performer on your team, you're sending a silent message to your top talent: "Excellence is optional here."

Your A-players are watching. They're taking notes. And they're asking themselves: "Why should I give 100% when others get away with 50?"

 What's holding you back from addressing underperformance?

posts.name:
Josh Roth
Josh Roth
posts.content:
Strategy tip: Stop strategizing in a vacuum.

Talk to your customers
Listen to customer calls
Talk with your salespeople who are on the frontlines

It’s tempting to try to be a spreadsheet hero and stay buried in spreadsheets and slide decks.

But that’s a fast track to missing your numbers.
Get out of your bubble. Talk to your teammates and customers

comments.commentText: The intersection of sales and AI will redefine how teams prioritize tasks and manage leads. It’s a game-changer for productivity.
Deepak Bhootra (Dr) You're not wrong here at all!
Put yourself in a position to truly learn and understand. Thinking solo is not enough
Alex Newmann It's crazy to see how many spreadsheet heroes exist when doing FY planning.

posts.name:
Marcus Chan
Marcus Chan
posts.content:
5-18 yrs old: Bus boy, dishwasher, cook, server, etc. at my parent's restaurant

18: My parents sold the rest. and I got a job selling speedos for $7.50/hr

19: Sold speedos and was an asst. swim coach

20: Sales intern selling insurance making $9/hr

21: Promoted to sales associate earning $9.50/hr

22: First B2B sales job. Almost fired after 60 days

23: Hit **#1** 9 months in a row and promoted 2X

24: Recession in full swing, the branch was consolidated. Demoted despite results. Decided to get my MBA at night

25: With a chip on my shoulder… destroyed numbers and got promoted 2X

26: MBA done. Decided to quit my job, take 2 steps back, and switch to a new company. In the first 6 months, my sales manager, directors and VP quit. I almost quit too but decided to keep going.

27: Became one of the top reps and promoted in 9 months to lead the team.

28: Turned the underperforming team into a perennial President's Club winning team.

29: Grew the team from 6 to 22 while maintaining the track record.

30: Promoted to director in 4.5 years in the Fortune 500 org with 85 employees. Scared and nervous if I could perform at this scale.

31: Hit Club first year as a director and decided to start a side hustle teaching others what I had done for 9 consecutive years.

32: Record-breaking results and lateral promotion to a training director over 230.

33: Internal company org shifts and back in the market director role. I'm disappointed but relieved at the same time. Grew the org to 110, kept breaking records, and stacking cash+equity.

35: After another Club year, decided to retire from corporate to go all in on my side hustle.

36: It's a rough year 1 and I wanted to quit daily. Ended up hitting 7-figures with the biz and was recognized as a LinkedIn Top Voice. Also ended up getting featured in Forbes, Yahoo! Finance, and more.

37: Started getting burnt out. Thought about quitting and then realized I needed to hire a team. Built a small team. The biz grew more.

38: With the extra capacity, wrote a book in 3 months and it became a WSJ Best Seller. Biz kept growing 

39: Made some bad hires and went backward in profitability for the first time. (My fault-should have vetted them more.) Questioned myself and wondered if I wanted to keep doing this.

40: This year. We're building something truly great. Our system gets some of the best and fastest results in the sales coaching industry. We're also building behind-the-scenes AI coaching products the world has never seen. Excited and optimistic for the future. The best is yet to come.

To all those fighting their own battles, we're all in the middle of writing our own stories.

The worse demons we face, the more epic the story.

You either get an inspiring outcome or an inspiring story.

Either way? You WIN.

So keep getting after it.

The only way you lose is if you QUIT.

May your internal desires be far greater than your obstacles.

Repost this to help inspire more people to keep going ️

comments.commentText:
Marcus Chan I wish everyone would work in a restaurant for at least a few months 
It'll teach them to appreciate customer service and those who do that work
Curt Sassak Yeah any service business. It's crazy how people treat you in that capacity vs if they saw you out of uniform.

Thanks for sharing your career journey Marcus Chan, you win or you learn for real, awesome to see how even after hitting multiple markers of success that life isn't linear and better things often come after going through new hells :). All the best to you and your business in 2025 my guy!
JJ Wong Thx, man! Appreciate it.

posts.content:
Preparation is battle half won!

Don't predict the future but prepare for it.

Don't think you are too small or too big to start something, take initiate if nobody else is there. You are not alone!

Be an asset to yourself and to the world.

The most beautiful part in the character of a person is the tendency to improve life of others and not just himself.

comments.commentText: Living for others is the most fulfilling way to live Md Shoaib
